title: Long- and Local-Range Structural Changes in Flexible Titanium Silicates with Variable Faulting upon Thermal Treatment and Corresponding Adsorption and Particle Size Polydispersity-Corrected Diffusion Parameters for CO

-UPRM-5 materials contained different amounts of structural faulting that are correlated to the formation of 12-MR pores. In situ high-temperature X-ray diffraction revealed structural changes corresponding to orthorhombic phases up to 300 °C. Analysis of in situ high-temperature
Si magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) spectroscopy revealed new silicon environments surrounding the archetypical Si(2Si, 2Ti

text: ) removal has been one of the most extensively studied topics for decades. This is, among other reasons, because CO
remains one of the main greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming.
In an attempt to address the problem at the source point, natural gas has been proposed as primary step in reducing the use of other fossil fuels such as oil and coal, which are higher CO

However, consumption of natural gas is now ramping up at an incredible pace because of shale gas fracturing expansion and the development of newer fracking technologies, allowing access to supplies that were unavailable before.
Therefore, methods to increase the efficient consumption of natural gas are mandatory to moderate its CO
emissions. Furthermore, the presence of CO
in gas mixtures also brings operational problems because it induces severe pipeline corrosion.
contains no heating value, its removal is also critical for avoiding a considerable decrease in methane’s (CH

capture technologies have been developed and employed during the last two decades; the process of absorption by aqueous amines is the most commonly used method. In fact, this is one of the most mature and well-established technologies in the natural gas industry. It permits rapid cycling with a sustained CO
removal capacity. Most amines have also good thermal stability and reactivity and allow for the removal of H

. However, these benefits come at the expense of considerable energy requirements because of high regeneration temperatures for which not all the amine solvent can be reused. The process also inherently involves the use of highly corrosive solvents, and their disposal can become an environmental hazard.
More recently, separation by hydrates and membranes has been proposed for CO
These have emerged during the last couple of years as sound methods because of low cost, fewer energy requirements, simple process flow schemes, and ease of operation.
However, there are some drawbacks in the use of some of these technologies such as low chemical and thermal stability and inefficiency in reducing CO
Another proposed alternative in competitive CO
remediation technology is the use of adsorbents in pressure swing adsorption (PSA) processes at ambient temperature.
Among many of the adsorbents that have been tested for PSA in the past, metal-based adsorbents, activated carbon, and zeolites have seen the greatest degree of commercial success.

This is mainly due to an overall reduction in energy use by the process. In addition, the relatively weak interactions between the adsorbate and the adsorbent result in ease of regeneration of the latter, requiring mechanical energy input lower than that required for the equivalent regeneration of amine solvents. In addition, the incorporation of these types of adsorbents in PSA systems could result in less capital and maintenance costs.
Most recently, certain metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been also identified as highly selective toward CO
and therefore offer tremendous potential for PSA. Different from other adsorbents in which thermodynamic equilibrium dominates the adsorption process, some of the most recent MOFs perform CO
separations based on differences in the rate of adsorption.
However, for kinetic separations to effectively take place during PSA operations, the size of the pores must be fairly close to that of the gas molecules to be adsorbed.
For most MOFs, the pore size specifications needed for CO

kinetic separation cannot be obtained by means of simple postmodification procedures. However, certain zeolitic formulations with pore sizes in the 3–4 Å range have been reconsidered for kinetic separations. Their relative ease of preparation and working capacities are attractive characteristics for the removal of CO
from flue gas, but the potential for increasing their selectivity toward CO
Flexible titanium silicates represent a good alternative for developing CO
selective adsorbent platforms because of their capacity for pore size reduction upon thermal dehydration and ease of modification for increasing it selectivity toward CO

. ETS-4 (Engelhard Corp., titanium silicate variant 4) was the first of these materials, and it is considered the standard in terms of adsorbents for the separation of similar-sized molecules such as CO

However, upon thermal activation the material working adsorption maximum capacity is considerably reduced as a consequence of structural contraction, which translates to more adsorption–regeneration cycles.

In this regard, a novel flexible titanium-silicate named UPRM-5, first developed by Primera-Pedrozo and Hernández-Maldonado, has exhibited a surface area larger than that of ETS-4, as well as larger adsorption capacities toward CO

. Marcano-González and Hernández-Maldonado also found that the UPRM-5 textural properties as well as thermal stability can be modified and controlled depending on the level of faulting in the structure, which can be adjusted depending on the type of quaternary ammonium cation employed as structure directing agent (SDA).
For instance, the use of tetrapropylammonium (TPA
) improved the UPRM-5 structural and textural characteristics for the adsorption of CO
A recent study by Yu et al. also showed the potential of using Sr
The contraction property of UPRM-5 upon thermal treatment was used to reverse selectivity in favor of N
, as has been done before for ETS-4.
kinetic separation can also be possible. Furthermore, the two UPRM-5 variants that have showcased the best performance for CO
removal so far have been Sr
Therefore, the present work focuses on the determination of the potential role of UPRM-5 prepared with different degrees of faulting to separate CO

based on both equilibrium and kinetic differences. The latter was based on diffusion data gathered using a volumetric transport model corrected for adsorbent particle size polydispersity. In addition, we have studied long- and local-range structural changes produced upon thermal contraction via indexing of in situ high-temperature X-ray diffraction (XRD) and
Si magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) spectroscopy, respectively. The thermal contraction characteristics were correlated to the adsorbents performance for CO

separation at different activation temperatures in attempt to understand the connection between faulting and performance and therefore pave the way for developing superior adsorbents based on the same platform.
The UPRM-5 variants considered for this work were synthesized by microwave-assisted hydrothermal reactions following methods available elsewhere.

Reaction times were 12 and 20 h when employing tetrapropylammonium and tetrabutylammonium  as SDAs, respectively. Detemplation and further modification of the samples were made by liquid ion-exchange with NH
For ease of identification, the strontium-modified materials will be labeled Sr
-UPRM-5 (TBA) depending on whether tetrapropylammonium or tetrabutylammonium cations were employed as SDAs, respectively.

Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were captured using a JEOL-JSM-6930LV unit working at a voltage range of 5.0–20.0 kV. The images were obtained following standard procedures for low conductive samples. The micrographs were used to determine the material morphology and particle length (
) distribution via direct sampling. The length distribution was then fitted to a cumulative Γ distribution function (
where α and β are the shape parameters of the distribution.

In situ high-temperature XRD data were collected using a high-temperature Reactor X (Rigaku Corporation) module attached to a Rigaku Ultima III system. This system allows enclosure of the sample powder with different gas atmospheres while permitting passage of X-rays through a continuous beryllium window and heating of the sample through an infrared-based heating element. The samples were placed on a removable black quartz plate, and the temperature was measured using a 1/16 in. diameter thermocouple that was placed inside an equally sized cylindrical hole located on one side of the quartz plate for accurate measurements. X-ray scans were gathered at 3.5° min
while the sample was heated from room temperature to 300 °C at 1 °C min
in flowing helium (ultrahigh purity grade, Praxair) at 60 mL min
. The resulting XRD data were indexed using the CRYSFIRE and the TREOR-90 routines.
Si MAS NMR spectra were collected on a Bruker DRX300NMR spectrometer with the
Si Larmor frequency of 59.63 MHz and using a 4 mm Bruker double-resonance variable temperature MAS probe. A 3.0 μs pulse (∼30° flip angle) was used for excitation of the

Si magnetization. A total of 8192 scans were used to accumulate the signals with a recycle delay of 5 s, except for the experiments during the cooling path at 135 and 72 °C, for which 4096 scans were used. The samples were sealed in the NMR rotor and spun at 6 kHz using N
gas. The temperature was controlled within ±0.1 °C by a Bruker BVT-2000 unit. The temperature was ramped from one temperature to the next higher temperature at a rate of 10 °C min
and then stabilized for about half an hour before data acquisition. The temperature was carefully calibrated independently using a lead nitrate sample spinning at 6 kHz by monitoring the plot of the

Pd chemical shift versus temperature. The chemical shift was referenced to DSS at 0 ppm. A 40 Hz exponential line broadening was used in the spectra. All spectra were deconvoluted using the SpinWorks NMR software.
Adsorption Equilibrium Isotherms and Fractional Uptake Data

adsorption equilibrium data were gathered volumetrically using a Micromeritics ASAP 2050 unit. The isotherms were obtained at 25 °C and pressures up to 7 atm. Degas or activation of the samples were carried out at 90 and 180 °C for Sr
-UPRM-5 (TBA), both under vacuum for 18 h. The first temperature corresponds to the optimal condition for achieving the largest surface area (i.e., 217 and 261 m
-UPRM-5 (TBA), respectively) while the second temperature yields a reduction of surface area of 65–84% depending on the adsorbent variant.

were used as received. The adsorption equilibration time was set to at least 100 s, and the apparent equilibrium state was corroborated by a near-zero slope condition present in at least 11 consecutive pressure transient points (i.e., a total of 1100 s worth of data per section per pressure step).

Fractional uptake data were gathered volumetrically using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument fitted with a turbo molecular drag pump. The data were collected at steps of 0.1 s and different pressures. In addition, the uptake data were corrected to compensate for the ASAP 2020 equipment effective dead time (ca. 0.3 s) and for any instability caused by the system.
The suitability of using a volumetric phenomenological transport model was carefully evaluated to determine the diffusional behavior of the studied gases into the adsorbents.

Framework contraction upon thermal treatment occurred uniformly as evidenced by the unit cell dimensions for both materials (Table S1 in

-UPRM-5 (TPA) showed a total unit cell volume reduction of ca. 32% when treated from 90 to 300 °C. The overall reduction involves a dual step contraction process, namely 90 → 180 °C (step I) and 240 → 300 °C (step II), probably related to the two-step dehydration mechanism previously reported based on thermal gravimetric analyses.
-UPRM-5 (TBA), on the other hand, exhibited a single-step unit cell volume reduction of ca. 7% in the 90 → 300 °C range. Lattice parameters

Two silicon environments were initially found in both UPRM-5 variants, similar to what has been reported for other titanium silicates. One is related to the octahedral titanium centers, Si(2Si, 2Ti
), located at around −93.0 ppm, while the other one is related to the semioctahedral titanium centers, Si(3Si, 1Ti
When increasing the temperature from 60 to 150 °C, the spectral stack shows a third resonance centered originally at around −89.0 ppm, which is also related to the Si(2Si, 2Ti
) environment. This is more apparent in Figure

, which shows chemical shifts and peak relative areas as a function of temperature. Chemical shifts for both materials remained similar and nearly constant up to 60 °C. However, as the temperature was increased further, peak relative areas underwent significant changes. As the temperature is increased, the relative area of the resonance associated with the semioctahedral titanium centers decreases (see data with triangle markers in Figure
). Semioctahedral titanium chains (or larger amount of structural faulting) are also associated with tenacious or coordinated water present in flexible titanium silicates.

-UPRM-5 (TPA) exhibited the most significant reduction in the amount of semioctahedral titanium centers, from ca. 50% to ca. 28%, within the 30–150 °C range. Because faulting in these materials will translate to significant differences in textural properties, the NMR data suggests that such properties plausibly correlate with the level of dehydration of the semioctahedral titanium centers.

The appearance of the corresponding resonance (i.e., initially centered at −89.0 ppm) and further increase in the peak relative area may be the consequence of perturbations of the octahedral titanium centers due to the release of coordinated water. This also seems to affect the semioctahedral titanium centers.
Material dehydration and plausibly thermal stress appear to also induce relocation of the Sr
cations, as suggested by the chemical shifts of the resonances related to the Si(2Si, 2Ti

) environments and initially located at −93.0 and −89 ppm. Such phenomena may occur because of deshielding of silicon atoms at temperatures higher than 90 °C. In general, these local changes seem related to framework contraction in Sr
-UPRM-5 and therefore could dictate adsorption and textural properties for UPRM-5 adsorbents. However, such changes have been shown to be more significant in the case of Sr
-UPRM-5 (TPA) and indicate perhaps more sensitivity toward thermal stimulus.

Adsorption studies made for ETS-4, which also contains a bimodal pore system, have shown that this feature results in poor prediction of adsorption–desorption diffusivities when traditional phenomenological transport models are employed.
The narrower channels in UPRM-5 correspond to the 8-MR pore system previously mentioned, which is characteristic of flexible titanium silicates.
The other dominant pore system is a result of the structural faulting, which is controlled by the choice of SDA and effectively results in larger pore dimensions.
Per the discussion of the XRD results, the 8-MR pores or channel system in Sr

-UPRM-5 (TBA) seems to be the most affected by thermal contraction during thermal activation. Also, because of the similarity in sizes between the 8-MR pore opening and the kinetic diameter of the adsorbates, i.e. CO
, these pores can be tailored for effective molecular sieving and therefore exert some control on the gas transport through the structure framework.

Thermally induced structural changes in Sr

-UPRM-5 (TBA) adsorbents were analyzed via in situ techniques. In situ XRD and careful indexing showed orthorhombic crystal structures and lattice parameters similar to those of zorite that remained upon dehydration even at high temperatures. The data also revealed that the 8-MR pore system in these materials is the most susceptible to contraction during thermal treatment in comparison to the pore system related to faulting. This might explain the differences in CO
adsorption loadings under equilibrium as well as diffusion rates. In situ
Si MAS NMR confirmed the important role of the semioctahedral titanium centers in the thermal contraction process.
-UPRM-5 (TBA) adsorbents were also analyzed to determine their capacity for kinetic separation of the CO
pair at ambient temperature. Kinetic selectivity values for CO
at an activation temperature of 120 °C reached a maximum of ca. 41 in the case of Sr
-UPRM-5 (TPA). For a hypothetical mixture of 4% CO
, the kinetic selectivity observed for the TPA
adsorbent variant was ca. 20. The results show the potential of using Sr
-UPRM-5-like materials as molecular sieves for PSA systems in the separation of CO
. However, fixed bed dynamic adsorption tests should be further performed to determine long-term reusability and bed diffusion performance for CO

Adsorption equilibrium and kinetics of CO2, CH4, N2O, and NH3 on ordered mesoporous carbon
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science

Ordered mesoporous carbon was synthesized by a self-assembly technique and characterized with TEM, Raman spectroscopy, and nitrogen adsorption/desorption for its phys. and pore textural properties.  The high BET sp. surface area (798 m2/g), uniform mesopore-size distribution with a median pore size of 62.6 Å, and large pore vol. (0.87 cm3/g) make the ordered mesoporous carbon an ideal adsorbent for gas sepn. and purifn. applications.  Adsorption equil. and kinetics of carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, and ammonia on the ordered mesoporous carbon were measured at 298 K and gas pressures up to 800 Torr.  The adsorption equil. capacities on the ordered mesoporous carbon at 298 K and 800 Torr for ammonia, carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide, and methane were found to be 6.39, 2.39, 1.5, and 0.53 mmol/g, resp.  Higher adsorption uptakes of methane (3.26 mmol/g at 100 bar) and carbon dioxide (2.21 mmol/g at 13 bar) were also obsd. at 298 K and elevated pressures.  Langmuir, Freundlich, and Toth adsorption equil. models were used to correlate all the adsorption isotherms, and a simplified gas diffusion model was applied to analyze the adsorption kinetics data collected at 298 K and four different gas pressures up to 800 Torr.

A review.  This article provides an overview of conventional and developing gas processing technologies for CO2 and N2 removal from natural gas.  We consider process technologies based on absorption, distn., adsorption, membrane sepn. and hydrates.  For each technol., we describe the fundamental sepn. mechanisms involved and the commonly applied process flow schemes designed to produce pipeline quality gas (typically 2% CO2, <3% N2) and gas to feed a cryogenic gas plant (typically 50 ppmv CO2, 1% N2).  Amine absorption technologies for CO2 and H2S removal (acid gas treating) are well-established in the natural gas industry.  The advantages and disadvantages of the conventional amine- and phys.-solvent-based processes for acid gas treating are discussed.  The use of CO2 selective membrane technologies for bulk sepn. of CO2 is increasing in the natural gas industry.  Novel low-temp. CO2 removal technologies such as ExxonMobil's Controlled Freeze Zone® process and rapid cycle pressure swing adsorption processes are also emerging as alternatives to amine scrubbers in certain applications such as for processing high CO2 concn. gases and for developing remote gas fields.  Cryogenic distn. remains the leading N2 rejection technol. for large scale (feed rates greater than 15 MMscfd) natural gas and liquefied natural gas plants.  However, technologies based on CH4 selective absorption and adsorption, as well as N2 selective pressure swing adsorption technologies, are com. available for smaller scale gas processing facilities. Adsorption equil. and kinetics of CO2, CH4, N2O, and N2 on two newly discovered adsorbents, metal-org. frameworks MOF-5 and MOF-177 and one traditional adsorbent, zeolite 5A were detd. to assess their efficacy for CO2, CH4, and N2O removal from air and sepn. of CO2 from CH4 in pressure swing adsorption processes.  Adsorption equil. and kinetics data for CO2, CH4, N2O, and N2 on all three adsorbents were measured volumetrically at 298K and gas pressures up to 800 Torr.  Adsorption equil. capacities of CO2 and CH4 on all three adsorbents were detd. gravimetrically at 298 K and elevated pressures (14 bar for CO2 and 100 bar for CH4).  The Henry's law and Langmuir adsorption equil. models were applied to correlate the adsorption isotherms, and a classical micropore diffusion model was used to analyze the adsorption kinetic data.  The adsorption equil. selectivity was calcd. from the ratio of Henry's consts., and the adsorbent selection parameter for pressure swing adsorption processes were detd. by combining the equil. selectivity and working capacity ratio.  Based on the selectivity and adsorbent selection parameter results, zeolite 5A is a better adsorbent for removing CO2 and N2O from air and sepn. of CO2 from CH4, whereas MOF-177 is the adsorbent of choice for removing CH4 from air.  However, both MOF adsorbents have larger adsorption capacities for CO2 and CH4 than zeolite 5A at elevated pressures, suggesting MOF-5 and MOF-177 are better adsorbents for CO2 and CH4 storage.  The CH4 adsorption capacity of 22 wt.% on MOF-177 at 298K and 100 bar is probably the largest adsorption uptake of CH4 on any dry adsorbents.  The av. diffusivity of CO2, CH4 and N2O in MOF-5 and MOF-177 is in the order of 10-9 m2/s, as compared to 10-11 m2/s for CO2, CH4 and N2O in zeolite 5A.  The effects of gas pressure on diffusivity for different adsorbate-adsorbent systems were also investigated.
SSZ-45: A High-Silica Zeolite with Small Pore Openings, Large Cavities, and Unusual Adsorption Properties
SSZ-45: A High-Silica Zeolite with Small Pore Openings, Large Cavities, and Unusual Adsorption Properties
Smeets, Stef; Xie, Dan; McCusker, Lynne B.; Baerlocher, Christian; Zones, Stacey I.; Thompson, Joshua A.; Lacheen, Howard S.; Huang, Hua-Min

Sepns. of small mols. such as CO2 and N2 or CH4 and CO2 are key to many industrial processes, but it is not always easy to find a mol. sieve that can discriminate between these mols. and withstand the harsh conditions often required.  The high-silica zeolite SSZ-45, which was synthesized using N-cyclopentyldiazabicyclooctane as the structure directing agent (SDA), was found to exhibit excellent thermal stability and rather unusual adsorption properties under pressure.  That is, it has potential in the area of small mol. sepns.  Of particular interest, therefore, was the structural basis for its peculiar adsorption behavior.  The relatively complex silicate framework structure of SSZ-45 was detd. from a combination of synchrotron powder diffraction and rotation electron diffraction data.  Once the framework was known, it was possible to locate the org. SDA in the cavities and to better understand its contribution to the formation of the zeolite.  The authors describe the synthesis of SSZ-45, the anal. of its structure, and the subsequent investigation of its small mol. sepn. properties.
